name: Resources Centre of Excellence and Future Industries Hub
summary: Paget: training, innovation, demonstration; Stage 2 Future Industries Hub supported with Queensland Government funding, focus including incubating new industries such as critical minerals processing.
description:
The Resources Centre of Excellence is a world-class facility located in the Greater Whitsunday region driving cutting-edge research, technology, education, and industry collaboration. Stage 2 — the Future Industries Hub — is focused on incubating new industries including critical minerals processing, with $5.7 million in Queensland Government funding under the Queensland Resources Industry Development Plan.

The facility includes the FlexiLab critical minerals pilot processing plant, underground coal mine simulator, and supporting infrastructure. It serves as a sector-agnostic innovation platform connecting METS businesses with emerging opportunities across the seven priority diversification sectors identified in the GW3 strategy.
nextStep: Finalise Stage 2 scope and common-user access model.
economicImpact: Part of $30-42bn Australian critical minerals pipeline; supports region's 700+ METS businesses
risks: Geographic perception barrier — METS businesses perceive critical minerals as relevant only to the North West Minerals Province
Capital constraints for scaling pilot demonstrations to commercial operations
Talent attraction challenges — negative association with mining deters school leavers and graduates
strategicActions: Promote critical minerals opportunities to local METS businesses, especially early exploration and planning services
Connect regional skills to North West Minerals Province development needs
Progress common-user infrastructure partnerships to pilot, expand, and relocate processing capabilities
skillsImplications: Downstream processing requires reskilling in battery production value chain, robotics, automation, metallurgical and chemical processes, and electrochemistry. Marketing campaigns needed in schools, TAFE, and universities to reposition METS as essential to decarbonisation.
marketDrivers: Global critical minerals market doubled to ~$400bn (2022). IEA forecasts 100-300% demand increase by 2040; lithium demand 40x higher. Australian pipeline valued at $30-42bn. Battery storage demand to increase tenfold by 2030.

governmentPrograms.name: Queensland Resources Industry Development Plan
governmentPrograms.description: Growth and diversification through new economy minerals

governmentPrograms.name: Clean Economy Jobs Act 2024
governmentPrograms.description: Legislated renewable energy and emissions targets

timeline.label: Stage 2 Future Industries Hub funding secured

name: RCOE FlexiLab critical minerals pilot processing plant
summary: Pilot processing facility in Paget supported with Queensland Government funding; interest from companies.
description:
One of Australia's first commercial common-user facilities for critical minerals processing, tailings reprocessing, and precious metals. The FlexiLab is part of the Resources Centre of Excellence in Paget, supported by $5.7 million in Queensland Government funding. Currently in its construction phase with high levels of industry interest from junior miners and established resources companies.

The facility addresses a critical gap in the Australian critical minerals value chain — the ability to pilot and demonstrate processing technologies at commercial scale without requiring individual companies to invest in dedicated infrastructure. This common-user model is designed to de-risk entry for METS businesses seeking to diversify into critical minerals processing.
nextStep: Secure offtake and finalise common-user access terms.
investmentValue: $5.7m Queensland Government funding (shared with Future Industries Hub)
economicImpact: Downstream refining and processing could generate an additional $140bn in GDP nationally between 2022-2040
risks: Difficulty scaling from pilot to commercial stage — significant additional investment required
METS businesses face opportunity costs diverting from strong coal pipeline revenue
Skills gaps in metallurgical and chemical processes, electrochemistry, and battery production
strategicActions: Progress common-user infrastructure partnerships for critical minerals processing
Map specific skills gaps and explore micro-credentialling and transferable skills pathways with TAFE and universities
Attract overseas talent where domestic supply is insufficient
skillsImplications: Requires reskilling in battery production value chain, robotics, automation, metallurgical and chemical processes. NWMP deposits estimated at $500bn create sustained demand for processing skills.
marketDrivers: Global critical minerals required for energy transition valued at $2.5 trillion+ by 2050. Queensland battery storage demand to increase tenfold by 2030, potentially generating up to $1.3bn economic activity.

governmentPrograms.name: Federal Climate Change Bill 2022
governmentPrograms.description: 43% emissions reduction by 2030, net zero by 2050

name: Capricornia Energy Hub pumped hydro concept
summary: Pumped hydro concept for the region; major project in renewable pipeline.
description:
Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners' proposed 1,400 MW Capricornia Energy Hub, located approximately 80km west of Mackay near Eungella Dam. The $2.5 billion pumped hydro energy storage project features a 750 MW pump/generation facility and represents one of the largest renewable energy investments in the Greater Whitsunday region.

Construction is expected to commence after 2025, creating approximately 600 jobs during construction and 65 regional operations jobs ongoing. The project addresses the critical need for dispatchable energy storage to support Queensland's transition to 70% renewables by 2032 and 80% by 2035.
economicImpact: ~600 construction jobs, 65 ongoing regional operations jobs. Part of $162bn Queensland renewable energy pipeline.
risks: METS businesses are waiting for critical mass of operational renewable assets before engaging
Limited awareness of construction-phase opportunities in transmission and pumped hydro
Specialised electrical trades gap — substation isolation, grid-scale energy storage skills not widely available
strategicActions: Collate and communicate the pipeline of renewable projects and METS-relevant skills requirements
Identify and define skills requirements and gaps for pumped hydro and transmission projects
Advocate for procurement processes that favour local businesses by breaking contracts into smaller packages
infrastructureNeeds: Local road and transport infrastructure upgrades
skillsImplications: Construction phase requires earthmoving, tunnelling, and fabrication — transferable from mining. Operations require specialised electrical commissioning, substation installation, and grid-scale energy storage system skills not currently available in the region.
marketDrivers: Queensland Energy and Jobs Plan requires $62bn total capital investment to 2035. 30+ solar, wind, and battery projects proposed in the region with 9+ GW collective generation capacity. ~$1bn already invested in 500+ MW of large-scale renewables since 2015.

governmentPrograms.name: Renewable Transformation Act 2024
governmentPrograms.description: 70% renewables by 2032, 80% by 2035, net zero by 2050

name: Pioneer-Burdekin pumped hydro concept
summary: Pumped hydro concept referenced for the region; significant investment pipeline.
description:
Queensland Hydro's proposed 5,000 MW Pioneer-Burdekin Pumped Hydro Energy Storage project, located approximately 75km west of Mackay. If developed, it would be the largest project of its kind in the world, with an initial cost estimate exceeding $12 billion. The Queensland Government indicated in February 2024 that costs will be higher than originally estimated.

The project would create over 3,000 jobs during construction, with delivery planned by 2035. It is currently in the early investigation and detailed technical study stage. The project is a centrepiece of Queensland's Energy and Jobs Plan and would provide massive dispatchable storage capacity to underpin the state's renewable energy transition.
nextStep: Scope regional participation and procurement opportunities.
economicImpact: 3,000+ construction jobs. Part of Queensland's $62bn energy transition investment to 2035. Would be the largest pumped hydro project in the world.
risks: Pioneer-Burdekin PHES requires specialist skills not currently available in the region or widely in Australia
Cost escalation — Queensland Government indicated costs will exceed initial $12bn estimate
Local manufacturing not being explored — significant opportunity for components but uncertain local procurement commitment
METS businesses see only O&M phase and are waiting for critical mass before engaging
strategicActions: Identify and define skills requirements and gaps specifically for pumped hydro construction
Encourage METS reskilling and upskilling for renewable energy construction and operations
Work with stakeholders on electrical services upskilling pathways
Support advanced manufacturing transition including big data, analytics, robotics, and automation
infrastructureNeeds: Road and transport infrastructure west of Mackay
Worker accommodation for remote construction site
skillsImplications: Would require specialist pumped hydro skills not currently available in region or widely in Australia. Construction phase requires earthmoving, tunnelling, and fabrication transferable from mining. 319 skills identified as being in shortage across Australia's energy transition.
marketDrivers: Queensland Government has estimated close to $8bn in further investment in the Greater Whitsunday region out to 2040. Pioneer-Burdekin is a centrepiece of the Energy and Jobs Plan. Global pumped hydro market growing as grid-scale storage becomes critical.

governmentPrograms.name: Queensland Energy and Jobs Plan
governmentPrograms.description: Centrepiece project of the state energy transition

timeline.label: Early investigation and detailed technical study stage

name: Linked Group Services diversification into commercial solar
summary: METS business diversifying into commercial solar solutions and products; awareness and specialised electrical capabilities noted as gaps.
description:
Linked Group Services is a Paget-based company that has successfully diversified from mining electrical contracting into commercial solar energy solutions. The company locally manufactures solar carport solutions, portable solar generators (EcoG3N, EcoSkid), and portable buildings, demonstrating the METS-to-renewables diversification pathway.

This case study represents a practical model for how METS businesses can leverage existing electrical and fabrication skills to capture renewable energy opportunities. However, scaling requires addressing awareness gaps and developing specialised electrical capabilities for grid-scale installations.
nextStep: Build construction-phase capability and procurement pathways.
economicImpact: Demonstrates METS-to-renewables diversification pathway. Part of regional 9+ GW renewable pipeline.
risks: Specialised electrical trades gap — commissioning, substation isolation, grid-scale energy storage systems
Limited awareness among METS businesses of construction-phase opportunities in renewables
High costs versus international suppliers creating uncertainty around local manufacturing viability
strategicActions: Collate and communicate pipeline of renewable projects and METS-relevant skills requirements
Work with stakeholders on electrical services upskilling
Advocate for procurement processes favouring local businesses
skillsImplications: Awareness and specialised electrical capabilities identified as primary gaps. Electrical commissioning, substation isolation and installation, and grid-scale energy storage system skills not currently widely available in the region.
marketDrivers: ~$8bn in further renewable investment expected in Greater Whitsunday to 2040. 30+ solar, wind and battery projects proposed regionally. Queensland targets 80% renewables by 2035.

timeline.label: Diversification from mining electrical contracting underway
Solar carport and portable generator products in market

name: Mackay QUT Renewable Biocommodities Pilot Plant and Racecourse Cogeneration
summary: Biocommodities pilot plant and sugar cogeneration; established bioenergy case studies.
description:
Located at Nordzucker Mackay Sugar's Racecourse Mill, the QUT Renewable Biocommodities Pilot Plant converts biomass into biofuels, green chemicals, and bioproducts. It is currently undergoing a $16 million upgrade co-invested by State and Federal Governments, QUT, and the Food and Beverage Accelerator, with planned completion in late 2024.

Once upgraded, it will become Australia's only facility capable of demonstrating synthetic biology processes at full scale. The adjacent Racecourse Cogeneration Plant already produces enough renewable energy to power approximately 30% of Mackay using bagasse. The Mackay State Development Area (907 hectares, declared February 2024) has been established to support this emerging biocommodity industry.
nextStep: Clarify market drivers and offtake for sustainable aviation fuels pathway.
investmentValue: $16m upgrade (State, Federal, QUT, Food & Beverage Accelerator co-investment)
economicImpact: Part of forecast $726bn global bioenergy market by 2050. Australian SAF industry could be worth $3bn annually and create 15,600 jobs by 2050. Potential $10bn annual GDP contribution to Australia's economy by early 2030s.
risks: Feedstock competition perception — METS businesses view bioenergy through lens of agricultural competition, unaware of contemporary by-product processes
Limited understanding of sustainable aviation fuel demand drivers among METS businesses
METS aligned only to construction and O&M; niche bioenergy skills (microbiology, biochemistry) not held by METS
Profitability perception — association with agriculture deters METS engagement
strategicActions: Develop tools and strategies to deliver bioenergy opportunity information to METS businesses
Facilitate engagement between METS and SAF/biofuels proponents
Identify and promote successful local case studies demonstrating commercial viability
Continue to monitor and communicate bioenergy sector opportunities across the value chain
infrastructureNeeds: Mackay State Development Area (907 hectares, declared Feb 2024)
skillsImplications: Broad skills gap — METS aligned to construction and O&M only. Niche bioenergy skills needed: microbiology, biochemistry, agricultural science, biomass production and management. Feedstock and land availability could become barriers as volumes increase.
marketDrivers: Global bioenergy market forecast at $726bn by 2050 (net zero scenario). Australian SAF industry could generate $3bn annually by 2050. Mercurius Rising Pilot Project using patented REACH technology to convert feedstocks into renewable drop-in fuels.

governmentPrograms.name: Queensland Biofutures 10-Year Roadmap 2016-2026
governmentPrograms.description: Greater Whitsunday positioned as biofutures hub

governmentPrograms.name: Mackay State Development Area
governmentPrograms.description: 907 hectares declared Feb 2024 for biocommodity industry

timeline.label: Full-scale synthetic biology demonstration capability operational

name: Wilmar Sarina Distillery (ethanol precinct)
summary: Sugar-to-ethanol precinct; established bioenergy presence; stakeholder perceptions on feedstock and demand drivers.
description:
Australia's largest sugarcane-to-ethanol producer, the Wilmar Sarina Distillery produces approximately 60 million litres of ethanol annually. The facility represents an established bioenergy presence in the region and a potential platform for newer biofuels pathways including sustainable aviation fuels.

While the distillery is operationally mature, its progression to new biofuel products is constrained by stakeholder perceptions around feedstock competition with agriculture and limited understanding of demand drivers for next-generation biofuels in aviation and shipping sectors where electrification is not viable.
nextStep: Secure offtake and articulate value chain for newer biofuels.
economicImpact: Existing major employer. SAF expansion could capture portion of $3bn annual Australian SAF industry by 2050.
risks: Feedstock competition perception between biofuels and agriculture
Limited understanding of SAF demand drivers among regional stakeholders
Association with agriculture (perceived as low profitability) deters METS engagement
Feedstock and land availability could become barriers as production volumes increase
strategicActions: Deliver bioenergy opportunity information to METS businesses demonstrating the demand case
Facilitate engagement between METS businesses and SAF/biofuels proponents
Promote Wilmar as a successful case study demonstrating bioenergy commercial viability
infrastructureNeeds: Sarina Distillery site and surrounding precinct
skillsImplications: Production operations skills are established. Expansion into newer biofuels requires additional skills in biochemistry, biomass management, and advanced process operations. METS construction and maintenance capabilities are transferable.
marketDrivers: Global bioenergy market forecast at $726bn by 2050. Australia could generate 26,200 new jobs in bioenergy by early 2030s. Aviation and shipping sectors require liquid fuels where electrification is not viable.

timeline.label: SAF pathway and next-generation biofuels exploration underway
Offtake agreement target for newer biofuels

name: Future Foods Biohub business case and Cauldron Ferm facility concept
summary: Future foods biohub business case partnership; pilot plant upgrades enabling synthetic biology demonstration; food-grade certification and process capability highlighted as constraints.
description:
The proposed $300 million Future Foods BioHub facility in the Mackay State Development Area would provide industry-led anchor infrastructure for commercial-scale biomanufacturing of innovative food products. The Queensland Government contributed $528,000 towards the business case, with over $1 million in total funding for development.

Cauldron Ferm, a key partner, plans to build the Asia-Pacific region's largest network of precision fermentation facilities. A key factor in choosing Mackay was the strong mining and METS capability — particularly fabrication of fermentation vessels, maintenance, quality control, industrial cleaning, and automation. The company is currently mapping skills and service requirements for future operations.
nextStep: Establish certification pathways and process capability building.
investmentValue: $300m proposed facility; $528k QLD Government business case contribution; $1m+ total development funding
economicImpact: Part of forecast $700bn global biomanufacturing market by 2040. Australia's potential: $29bn annually and 50,000 new jobs by 2040. Queensland sector could contribute $4bn+ to gross state product by 2035.
risks: Food-grade certification gap — existing METS equipment used for mining products cannot service food applications without certification
Limited technical understanding of precision fermentation and biomanufacturing for food (in its infancy in Australia)
Process operators will outnumber scientists; METS businesses don't understand how to transfer mining optimisation capabilities
Controlled environment operations differ fundamentally from typical METS working environments
strategicActions: Identify food-grade skills requirements and streamline certification pathways
Map specific skills needs and gaps; explore micro-credentialling and transferable skills pathways with TAFE and universities
Develop customised training modules leveraging expertise of industry, universities, and TAFE
Facilitate opportunities to increase METS understanding of biomanufacturing processes
skillsImplications: High alignment in fabrication of fermentation vessels, maintenance/repair, quality control, industrial cleaning, robotics and automation. Limited alignment in microbiology, biochemistry, bioprocess engineering, food safety and regulatory compliance. $363m in private capital invested in Australian biomanufacturing companies 2021-2023.
marketDrivers: Global biomanufacturing market forecast at $700bn by 2040 (up from $11.8bn in 2021). 80% of private investment in agriculture and food. Cauldron Ferm chose Mackay specifically for METS capability alignment.

governmentPrograms.name: Mackay State Development Area
governmentPrograms.description: Declared Feb 2024; 907 hectares for significant industry

timeline.label: $528k QLD Government business case contribution secured
Cauldron Ferm mapping skills and service requirements

name: RCOE and BHP Mitsubishi Pit to Port circular program
summary: Circular program associated with Resources Centre of Excellence; mining value chain; limited circular systems thinking and mine site control practices noted.
description:
A first-of-its-kind national pilot program between the Resources Centre of Excellence and BHP Mitsubishi Alliance to understand the scope for integrating circular economy principles across the entire mining value chain — from pit to port. The program includes a comprehensive material flow analysis of all mining waste to identify impact hotspots and catalytic circular opportunities.

A follow-on phase will support businesses to implement recommendations. The program is complemented by the $4 million Queensland Circular Economy (Industry-Research) Program implemented through the Resources Centre of Excellence to support development of business solutions using circular economy principles.
nextStep: Align stakeholders and navigate regulatory and site-control barriers.
economicImpact: Part of $6.5 trillion+ global circular economy value by 2030. Australia: $1.8tn in direct benefits over two decades. Mining tailings reprocessing: $4.9tn global opportunity.
risks: Lack of circular systems thinking — businesses focused on recycling rather than lifecycle thinking
Uncertain downstream demand for product-as-a-service models and circular value propositions
Stringent mine site waste compliance restricts reuse and repurposing of waste materials
Knowledge gaps on waste material uses and regulation around waste management
strategicActions: Communicate regional circular economy findings to METS businesses; increase lifecycle thinking skills
Work with stakeholders to identify demand for alternative circular business models
Advocate for adapting waste management regulations to enable innovative repurposing while maintaining environmental standards
Partner with stakeholders to link METS businesses with information on waste material uses
infrastructureNeeds: Paget Industrial Estate for circular processing
skillsImplications: METS businesses need capability uplift from basic recycling to full lifecycle thinking. Off-road tyres represent significant opportunity — Greater Whitsunday is one of the highest off-road tyre generating regions nationally. 80% of a product's environmental impact is locked in during design and manufacturing stages.
marketDrivers: Australia's circularity rate is only 4% (half the global average) — significant untapped potential. Global circular economy transaction revenue ~$490bn in 2022. Could save 165 million tonnes CO2/year by 2040.

timeline.label: Pit to Port pilot program initiated

name: Valmar Engineering supplying Gilmour Space
summary: Supply chain adjacency to Bowen Orbital Spaceport; licensing noted; gaps in accreditation and procurement pathways including ISO standards.
description:
Valmar Engineering is a Greater Whitsunday company established in 2013 with sugar and mining fabrication experience. Since September 2023, Valmar has been fabricating the transport erector and associated components to take the 30-tonne Gilmour Space rocket from horizontal to vertical position for launch at the Bowen Orbital Spaceport.

The Bowen Orbital Spaceport — co-funded by the Australian and Queensland Governments and Gilmour Space Technologies — was granted a launch facility licence in March 2024. It is one of only three dedicated orbital launch sites globally, located near Bowen due to proximity to the equator, low population density, and existing infrastructure including a deep-sea port, long runway, and road/rail network. Over 30,000 satellites globally are awaiting launch, creating a severe bottleneck in launch capacity.
investmentValue: Government co-funded spaceport; Valmar contract for transport erector components
economicImpact: Global space economy estimated at $2.6tn by 2035. Australian Space Agency target: triple to $12bn/year and create 20,000 additional jobs by 2030. Queensland potential: $3.5-6bn annually by 2036.
risks: Limited demand visibility — METS businesses see limited short-term market (small number of launches planned)
Skills transfer uncertainty — STEM and safety design competencies applicable but transition pathway not well understood
Certification and compliance barrier — ISO accreditations perceived as major barrier to entry
Scale mismatch — space manufacturing is much smaller scale than mining; quality demands extremely high
strategicActions: Develop stakeholder engagement plans connecting METS businesses to space opportunities
Identify skills and qualifications for enhancing existing METS capabilities for space
Enhance and promote procurement requirements and opportunities in the space sector
Map accreditation pathways modelled on defence supply chain entry processes
skillsImplications: 319 skills required in the space industry; 310 identified as being in shortage (SmartSat CRC). High alignment: manufacturing, heavy equipment maintenance, electrical trades, mechanical and fabrication skills. Limited alignment: spacecraft mechanism design, crew habitation structures, debris shield design.
marketDrivers: Over 30,000 satellites awaiting launch globally — severe bottleneck in launch capacity. Space economy growing from $915bn (2023) to $2.6tn by 2035. 50% of world's top 10 aerospace companies have Queensland presence.

governmentPrograms.name: Australian Space Agency targets
governmentPrograms.description: Triple space economy to $12bn/year and +20,000 jobs by 2030

timeline.label: Valmar began fabrication for Gilmour Space
Bowen Orbital Spaceport launch licence granted

name: Veolia Woodlawn Eco Precinct
summary: External example included in PDF; post-mining land use; lack of clarity on who carries ongoing risk; need for regional strategic planning frameworks.
description:
An external reference case study from New South Wales included in the GW3 strategy. The Veolia Woodlawn Eco Precinct is a 6,000-hectare former zinc and copper mine site near Canberra that has been converted into a bioenergy plant, 48.3 MW wind farm, 2.5 MW solar farm, plus agriculture, aquaculture, and horticulture operations.

This model demonstrates the potential for post-mining land use in the Greater Whitsunday region, where peak Bowen Basin mine closure periods are expected around 2040 and 2070. Australian mine closure and remediation expenditure is estimated at $4-8 billion annually from 2023 to 2040, with approximately 1,000 mines expected to close globally by 2032.
nextStep: Establish governance and risk allocation clarity.
investmentValue: Reference case; regional opportunity estimated at $4-8bn annually (Australia-wide mine closure expenditure)
economicImpact: Australian environmental remediation technology/services market: $800m (2020), estimated to grow to $3bn by 2040. 25% of METS businesses nationally already offer mine closure solutions.
keyStakeholders: Queensland Government (Office of the Mine Rehabilitation Commissioner)
risks: Queensland mine closure regulation mandated rehabilitation only (grazing/native vegetation), not incentivising alternate land uses
Unclear which party carries ongoing risk for post-mining uses after rehabilitation
METS businesses need understanding of environmental, social, and community constraints
Scaling pilot approaches to commercial viability requires significant government support
Limited METS skills in ecological restoration, biodiversity conservation, and hydrology
strategicActions: Advocate for clear regulations supporting economic diversification in post-mining land use
Connect METS businesses to information on new economic models and legislative compliance
Develop regional strategic planning framework with Indigenous, community, research, government, investment, and industry stakeholders
Collaborate on proposals for targeted government incentive schemes to encourage innovative post-mining outcomes
skillsImplications: Limited METS skills in ecological restoration, biodiversity conservation, hydrology, and assessment of alternate land use. Best practice emphasises proactive action during mine operation including progressive rehabilitation, regular monitoring, and planning services.
marketDrivers: Peak Bowen Basin mine closure periods expected around 2040 and 2070. ~1,000 mines expected to close globally by 2032. Alternative land uses being explored include renewable energy, agriculture, recreation/tourism, aquaculture, industrial parks, and manufacturing.

governmentPrograms.name: Queensland Office of the Mine Rehabilitation Commissioner
governmentPrograms.description: Technical studies on post-mining land use in the Bowen Basin
